image.altText: Rodney Croome arrested in 1988

props.synopsis: A nation-first financial redress scheme has passed Tasmania's parliament for people convicted under past laws against homosexuality and cross-dressing.

title.children: Tasmania was the only state to criminalise 'cross-dressing', now victims can seek compensation for past convictions

image.altText: A map covering his face stands in a tiny room with plates on the floor and blankets hanging on the wall

props.synopsis: The Rohingya ethnic minority are being forcibly conscripted by Myanmar's military and rebel groups to fight in the civil war.

title.children: Kidnapped by rebels and forced into someone else's war, the Rohingya face a new nightmare

image.altText: Anthony Albanese speaks at a lectern with Anika Wells and Jim Chalmers beside him.

props.synopsis: For those with long political memories, there has been a bit of deja vu all over again in federal politics this week.

title.children: Buried in this week's aged care reforms was an idea that once cost two ministers their jobs

image.altText: A man in a blue suit stands in front of a podium, in front of an Australian flag.

props.synopsis: As Tasmania's public sector workers admonish the government's belt tightening, the treasurer has not ruled out selling state-owned assets to help balance the books.

title.children: 'We'd be open to an individual asset being considered': Tasmania's treasurer may look to sell public assets to temper ballooning debt

image.altText: snow speckled mountain can be seen behind buildings at elizabeth pier in hobart tasmania

props.synopsis: Spring's infamous variability will be on full display this weekend, delivering a blast of cold Antarctic air and potentially the coldest September weather in decades.

title.children: Antarctic air mass to deliver weekend snow, hail and thunder to eastern Australia

image.altText: Donald Trump speaks at a press conference.

props.synopsis: While Democrats hope Donald Trump debate rhetoric will turn off undecided voters, the former president is doubling down, even flooding his social media accounts with "Cats for Trump" memes.

title.children: Trump faced backlash for claiming pets were being eaten in Ohio. This is why he's not backing down

image.altText: an aerial photo of a gas well.

props.synopsis: Fracking projects in the Beetaloo Basin will face fresh scrutiny as the federal environment minister orders an assessment into the potential water impacts on gas exploration in the basin.

title.children: NT fracking projects facing fresh scrutiny with potential for 'water trigger' to be pulled

image.altText: Man in striped suit walking down steps

props.synopsis: Justice Gregory Geason pleaded not guilty to assault and emotional abuse or intimidation, saying the alleged victim stumbled and fell. But a Crown prosecutor described his account as "contrived and false".

title.children: 'Contrived and false': Prosecutor disputes Supreme Court judge's version of alleged assault

image.altText: Graphic image of a boy, a letter and barbed wire

props.synopsis: Weeks before he took his own life behind bars, the 17-year-old boy at the centre of the latest tragedy engulfing WA's Department of Justice said he wanted to turn his life around. But he didn't live to see his next birthday.

title.children: Ben wrote he didn't want to go to an adult jail. He never made it to 18

image.altText: Close up of woman's face as she looks upward and reflects on the environment around her

props.synopsis: At the heart of the Tarkine is Australia's largest tract of cool temperate rainforest, but parts of this awe-inspiring wilderness remain unprotected from native tree logging.

title.children: Marta Dusseldorp ventures into the heart of Tasmania's 'spectacular' ancient rainforest

image.altText: Two young boys and a woman pose in an front of a tree with yellow leaves. The faces of the boys and the woman are blurred.

props.synopsis: The woman, 42, was released from hospital today and taken to Parramatta Police Station where she was charged.

title.children: Mother charged with DV-related murder over the deaths of her two sons in Blue Mountains

image.altText: an aerial view of a lithium ore crushing facility

props.synopsis: Commodity prices are being walloped. For a nation like Australia that relies upon mineral exports, the consequences could be significant.

title.children: A commodity slump has run a bulldozer over our miners, and our export income

image.altText: A composite photo of Japan's Economics Minister Sanae Takaichi and Foreign Minister Yoko Kamikawa.

props.synopsis: Two women are in the running to lead Japan's Liberal Democratic Party and thus be virtually guaranteed to become the country's first female prime minister.

title.children: Why a woman becoming Japan's PM won't necessarily be good for gender equality

image.altText: A street sign that says Matsumoto street with red dirt in the background and a blue sky

props.synopsis: Petrol is $2, coffee is $6.50 and the average rental is $750 a week, yet this town is home to some of the most impoverished communities in Western Australia. What's gone wrong?

title.children: Gentrification means this family can't afford to buy a house on a street that's named after them

image.altText: On the right, an archival photo of a smiling man. On the left an orange background and a mask outline of his face

props.synopsis: Artificially generated images, video and audio have flooded the internet in recent years. Take our quiz to see if you can tell real from fake.

title.children: Can you spot AI like a verification journalist? Take our quiz

image.altText: arms export AAP Joel Carrett

props.synopsis: The main organisers of Wednesday's protest outside the Melbourne Exhibition and Convention Centre were Students for Palestine and anti-war group Disrupt Land Forces.

title.children: Protesters injured by foam bullets and 'excessive force' in Land Forces protests weigh up legal action

image.altText: A man celebrates winning a rugby league match

props.synopsis: After their thumping return to form against the Roosters, Penrith have sent yet another reminder of their unquenchable thirst for greatness.

title.children: There must be an antidote to Penrith's brutal and brilliant formula, but good luck finding it

image.altText: The brain of a teen girl

props.synopsis: Mental health disorders among young people have risen nearly 50 per cent in the past 15 years. We go inside a teen brain to show how modern pressures impact the adolescent mind and where it can go wrong.

title.children: How can you help a teen with depression or anxiety? Experts say this is what's important to know

image.altText: A composite image of a woman in the middle and two men to either side of her.

props.synopsis: ACT Labor have been in power for nearly 23 years, putting them among Australia's longest-serving governments.

title.children: 'It's become a bit one-sided': Antony Green says the ACT has fallen into a pattern of 'forever government'. So will anything change?

image.altText: Officer Cadets on parade at ADFA.

props.synopsis: Jake Sullivan is on trial in the ACT Supreme Court for the alleged rape of a female cadet at the Australian Defence Force Academy (ADFA) in Canberra.

title.children: Woman who alleges she was raped at ADFA tells court she felt 'alone' and 'vulnerable' in the aftermath

image.altText: A young white school boy holding a book, sitting next to a middle aged white woman smiling

props.synopsis: The ABC has been given rare access to two of the country's little-known free private schools that exist to serve disadvantaged students.

title.children: This school provides free meals and 50-week terms to stop students missing out on an education

image.altText: Three young men, one Black and two white, sit on chairs in blue and yellow shirts speaking to each other

props.synopsis: Citizens of the US, UK, Belgium and France have been convicted of participating in a coup attempt against the Congolese government in May this year.

title.children: Six foreigners sentenced to death in Democratic Republic of Congo

image.altText: A group of people crowded onto a small boat, on brown water level with the rooves of buildings.

props.synopsis: Hundreds of villagers in Myanmar saw severe floods around the remote capital of Naypyidaw on Friday while Vietnam began clearing up after the deadly Typhoon Yagi ripped through the country.

title.children: Typhoon Yagi barrels into Myanmar as death toll in Vietnam rises to 254

image.altText: one man talking with another standing behind him

props.synopsis: The curtain has drawn on the last sitting of parliament ahead of the state election.

title.children: Katter's party gains ex-One Nation MP and 'a gag of the most horrific order' as Queensland election countdown begins

image.altText: A man wearing a suit seated, with parts of the Russian flag in the background

props.synopsis: Russia's Federal Security Service (FSB) says it has revoked the accreditation of six British diplomats in Moscow whose actions it said showed signs of spying and sabotage work.

title.children: Russia expels six British diplomats in response to 'numerous unfriendly steps' taken by UK

image.altText: Back of man praying with hands up.

props.synopsis: In 2008, journalist Adriana Carranca was living in Kabul when she heard about a local pizza shop run by fellow Brazilians. The owners were on a secret mission, but not the type she expected.

title.children: Pizza shop owners by day, missionaries by night. Why a family risked death to convert Afghan Muslims to Christianity

image.altText: A young woman in a red t-shirt holds political pamphlets while standing outside a building.

props.synopsis: When 19-year-old Libby Austin stuck up her hand to be a ballot warmer in this weekend's local government elections, she never expected to win.

title.children: Sydney teenager became an accidental councillor thanks to Liberal Party's nominations blunder

image.altText: Kim Jong Un with two men in military uniform and two men in white shirts standing among rows of grey pipes.

props.synopsis: North Korea has offered its first glimpse into a secretive facility used to produce weapons-grade uranium.

title.children: North Korea offers first glimpse of secretive weapons-grade uranium facility — see inside

image.altText: A man in a white shirt holds a framed image with white gloves; the image shows a girl and a heart-shaped balloon.

props.synopsis: Two men have been charged with burglary over the theft of an artwork by Banksy from a London gallery.

title.children: Two men charged over theft of Banksy's Girl With Balloon painting

image.altText: Timberlake looks contrite with his gaze down while wearing a t shirt and double string of pearls

props.synopsis: The former *NSYNC singer was arrested in June after running a stop sign in New York state, but made a plea deal with prosecutors to avoid a criminal conviction.

title.children: Justin Timberlake pleads guilty to drink driving

image.altText: An Australian coach talks to a player during a break between games in an international team tennis event.

props.synopsis: Australia's team qualifies for the Davis Cup finals, delighted to reach the Malaga eight-team showdown on their day off.

title.children: Hewitt's Aussies clinch Davis Cup finals spot on their day off

image.altText: A portrait photo of a police officer standing in the sunshine on a beach, looking into the distance.

props.synopsis: From managing tsunami warnings to rescuing hikers in distress, Senior Constable Joel Merchant's days are never the same, as he keeps the peace on remote Lord Howe Island.

title.children: What's it like being the only police officer in paradise?

image.altText: An England batsman watches the ball go for four after hitting a shot square on the offside against Australia.

props.synopsis: A five-wicket haul by Australia's Matt Short cannot stop England — led by a brilliant knock of 87 by big-hitting Liam Livingstone — from winning the second T20 international in Cardiff, to level the series.

title.children: Matt Short's five-for not enough as Liam Livingstone and England level T20I series

image.altText: A man on a boat looking at mussels

props.synopsis: Mussels, long regarded as little better than fish bait, are now sold as a gourmet delicacy — and veteran fisherman Lance Wiffen says farming them sustainably is also helping the environment.

title.children: From fish bait to fine dining — now mussel farming is cleaning up Port Phillip Bay

image.altText: Supercars driver Jack Le Brocq driving his blue race car around a corner at speed at Sandown Raceway

props.synopsis: As Sandown celebrates 60 years of endurance racing, the future of the iconic Melbourne track remains in the balance.

title.children: Future of Sandown uncertain as Supercars mull 2025 season
